answer: You made it. The kids are just coming. They're not over the moon about going to the beach house. I ought to warn you.

question: Why didn't you say? I could have fixed up something else. I thought it would be a good place to get to know them again...
answer: Well, I figured you should be * allowed to make your own mistakes. It's only for a couple of nights, they can take it... and you'll learn... Check into a hotel if it gets too much... they like hotels. She shouts into the house. Come on, you two... your father's ready to go... She hands Hector a piece of paper. This is where we'll be, if anything crops up... thanks for the break... Hector gets a little scared about what he has taken on.

question: Maybe this is a bit sudden for them... Maybe I should have come over a couple of nights and got to know them...
answer: By Monday, you'll know them... Here he is, the invisible dad. That's what they call you.

question: Right... it's your name... you * can do that... Safeway... keep your * eyes skinned... and I could murder * a Chicken McNugget. * What's wrong with that? It's a kitchen roll... why can't I pick a kitchen roll?
answer: It's bleached... and it isn't recycled... you don't care... you just buy junk... She picks up a more friendly brand of kitchen towel from the shelf and throws it into the cart. Hector has the sense to back down.

question: Good point, Betsy... Betsy keeps on the attack.
answer: Everything you buy is junk... I don't eat steak... and what's this... She prods a packet of frozen hamburgers. Ugh! Why don't you ask us what we like... it'll save you money... you buy junk, we won't eat it... A trace of girlish common sense has crept into her voice. Hector warms to her.

question: You're right. Well, get to it... I'll just tag along...
answer: I do it every week anyway.

question: How about some eggs? They shake their heads. You don't eat eggs?
answer: How many have you got in there?

question: Three. Is that all right?
answer: For a week, maybe.

question: How about pancakes, Betsy... d'you like pancakes?
answer: Not much... why?

question: I just wondered. Pancakes don't mean much to you?
answer: They don't mean a thing. Why?

question: Nothing. The mystery of Betsy's pancake dream is evidently lost in infinity. Hector changes the subject. I thought we could walk into town this morning. I saw the Funfair when we came through last night.
answer: We don't go to Funfairs.

question: Let's take the walk anyway.
answer: I brought some books. I want to stay home and read. Hector is determined to make it work.

question: No. We're taking a walk.
answer: It's going to rain... we should stay.

question: Here's an umbrella... and there must be some old coats in here... and shoes... I only have these I'm wearing...
answer: Donald has some shoes...

question: I don't know if I want to wear Donald's shoes.
answer: Why not? Hector declines to explain the complex reasons that he might have for not wanting to wear the shoes of his children's replacement father. He sits down on the * stairs to put them on. Then something on the wall catches his eye.

question: Wow. Look at this. The kids' heights have been marked on the wall on some long-ago holiday. The dates are beside them. Six years ago. Look at that... What's this?
answer: That was the flood. The sea came right up. Donald says it's the icecap melting. It's going to get worse. That's why Mom's selling the place.

question: It comes up every year?
answer: The last two.

question: Where are the birds? Is it the wrong time of year?
answer: They don't come over so much. The shellfish have gone... that's what...

question: That's what Donald says?
answer: Yes... and it happens to be true.

question: Please don't rain... please... Let's have a ride... He has stopped at some dated space rockets.
answer: The seats are wet. Hector triumphs. He pulls a wad of kitchen roll from his pocket and starts to wipe the seats.

question: Kitchen roll, unbleached, re-cycled, biodegradable... dry seats... Betsy has the grace to smile as the three of them climb aboard the rockets. This is ridiculous. Let's go somewhere and talk. Betsy smiles her small patient smile.
answer: All right, if you want to... Hector looks to Thomas. Thomas vigorously nods his agreement. Hector is happier. He looks down on the decrepit fairground.

question: I wasn't in great shape... I sure didn't want you to see me then... so I got back to work... in real estate... found a partner, we met * in jail... *
answer: That's what you do now?

question: Yes. We rent apartments... but we want to get into commercial property... people are a nuisance... does that sound bad? Betsy shrugs her shoulders.
answer: How should I know? Hector carries on with his story.

question: Just recently I've been feeling good, things have been going well... and I missed you two... so here we are...
answer: What about your girl friend?

question: Who told you about her?
answer: Nobody.

question: What do you mean? Is that what you thought? I was avoiding you two? No... you mustn't think that... that's terrible... They have almost exhausted themselves in this first bout of talking. Hector looks out at the sea. The rain's off. Let's go.
answer: I have to ask you something else.

question: Go on.
answer: Why did you leave just two days before my swimming test? Hector is moved by the depth of her memory, her pain.

question: I didn't leave because it was two days before your test... it was just what your mother and I decided... I taught you how to swim... we went to the pool twice a week... why would I leave?
answer: I know... that's what I mean... why did you leave just then? Hector looks at Betsy. She is beginning to cry silently. He puts a tentative arm around her shoulder.

question: Oh, God, Betsy. I'm sorry.
answer: It doesn't matter.

question: How did you do, in the test?
answer: I passed. Hector leaves his limp arm on her shoulder. It is too * soon for gestures of emotion. After a long moment she speaks. I'm a life-saver now.

question: Hey, Thomas! We're going home... we're having a barbecue... Betsy said she'll even let me eat a steak! Don't call him Tom, he doesn't like it.
answer: I'm allowed. Somehow Hector is touched by this.

question: Your mother said it, when we split up... don't lose the children... didn't mean much at the time. But she was right.
answer: Who said I'd let you eat a steak? There is a silence. Then Hector speaks.

question: Betsy. On Monday will you come with me when I take the flowers back to Anna? I can't face her alone. She wants to meet you anyway.
answer: Sure.

question: You'll be there, right beside me?
answer: I'd have to take the morning off school.

question: Is that bad?
answer: No, that could be good...

question: Just tell them you were with your invisible dad.
answer: What's she like? How did you meet her?

question: The funny thing is I fell in love with her before I ever saw her... I smelled her... It was the day I got out of jail... I was on the train and she was sitting behind me... it was just this incredible perfume... remember I'd been inside for nearly two years with four hundred sweating males... She got off the train and I followed her... I couldn't help it... that's how good she is... she listened to a bum who followed her off a train... Betsy looks at him kindly. ... but she's still going to kill me on Monday...
answer: I think I'll paint the sunset tonight.

question: It's just like a big pancake up there, isn't it? Betsy doesn't take the bait. There is a silence. I remember when you two were tiny.. I used to watch you sleeping... it was like now... I felt close to you, could touch you... but you weren't there... you were gone... dreamland ... just when I was closest to you, you weren't there... I felt it last night, too.
answer: That's what it's like... you should know that.

question: I'm not smart about things like that, usually.
answer: Don't be so tough on yourself. You seem to want to be... you don't have to...

question: No?
answer: No... we can do that...

question: Is that a joke?
answer: No, I mean it... look out for yourself... Hector looks at her in wonderment. One of those moments when another human being stands before you and is an utter mystery.

question: Who are you? Who's inside there?
answer: You'll never know. Future generations of women are going to be just as unknowable to our Hectors as past ones were. Betsy moves off briskly along the beach. Hector trails after her, hooked. I thought he was taller.

question: I suppose so. He's getting fat, too. I bet I could beat him at the breast-stroke now.
answer: Come on in, kids... that boat doesn't look too safe... They call back to him.

question: We're fine! Hector tries to relax, but he doesn't have the confidence yet, or something. He is edgy.
answer: I've just found you... I don't want to lose you. What would I tell your mother... come on in... Throw me the rope, Thomas, I'll pull you in. Thomas throws the mooring rope to Hector. It isn't attached to the boat. Hector ends up with all of the rope in his hands. He stands there, and they all laugh. This is one useless piece of rope, Thomas...

question: Why does it always go so fast...? Thomas is laughing at her. He has seen her attempt this before. Hector has other concerns. He is trying to light his barbecue. Match after match disappears into his elaborate stone structure, only to fizzle out.
answer: I used to know how to do this... I did... I used to be really good at this... He wafts and blows ineffectually at a flicker of flame. There's not much of the caveman about him now. Ah... smell it... the smell of civilization... scorched meat... Hector serves the chicken onto their plates. He sits down beside them with his steak, and a glass of wine. He watches Thomas attack his chicken, and smiles. I'd forgotten that... how you eat... dedicated... like it's your religion!

question: I used to know how to do this... I did... I used to be really good at this... He wafts and blows ineffectually at a flicker of flame. There's not much of the caveman about him now. Ah... smell it... the smell of civilization... scorched meat... Hector serves the chicken onto their plates. He sits down beside them with his steak, and a glass of wine. He watches Thomas attack his chicken, and smiles. I'd forgotten that... how you eat... dedicated... like it's your religion!
answer: Things I like.

question: You used to hum to yourself too, when you ate... like everything was fine with the world. Thomas tries it out, eating and humming. It feels good to him. His head nods with the chewing and the tune.
answer: Hey, so I did... I'd forgotten about that...

question: There she is... old Mercury...
answer: No... Mercury doesn't rise 'til after midnight... that's Jupiter... Hector is impressed by his son.

question: I'd forgotten... we used to watch * the stars... you could tell me the * names of all the planets... you * could recite them like a poem... remember... at the tiny window upstairs in the old house?
answer: No.

question: Oh well, not to worry. I'm glad you still like astronomy though.
answer: I'm not into star-gazing so much ... we're working on computer modelling... we're trying to make a biosphere...

question: Uh-huh?
answer: A self-sustaining life system... for inter-stellar travel. But we always get a methane build up, it doesn't matter what we do...

question: This is at school?
answer: Yeah. We're making such a mess of the world, one day we're going to have to take off for somewhere else...

question: Sounds like Donald said that... Well, I'm glad you two are thinking about the old planet. I'm proud of you. Look how beautiful everything is. Sometimes I think it's people that make it all wrong... we walk around with all our problems...
answer: I don't know. If it wasn't for us there'd be nobody around to see it all. Hector stands to fetch another baked potato from the fire. We see the three of them in a WIDE SHOT, the evening sky now pulsing with more and more points of light. Hector's voice and laughter carry to us.

question: Don't worry, you two... I'll tell you... it's just a big, black sheet up there with holes in it so the light comes through... that's the truth... the very latest... Hector has come to rest, and found peace at last, however temporary, here on the beach, beneath the same stars that our first Hector wailed at six thousand years ago. On Monday he will face the music. The kids will go back home, Mrs. Philippopolis will have to be dealt with, and the wilting three hundred dollar bouquet of flowers. In general, life will take over, on Monday. But at this moment of calm on the beach, let's leave him while he's ahead.
answer: Wait a minute... I know... the whole universe is inside a speck of dust that's lying in a ball of fluff in the cuff of a pair of pants hanging over the back of a chair...

question: No... I'll tell you... the whole thing... stars and everything... is sitting on the skin of a bubble of milk in a bowl of cornflakes... and somebody's just about to eat it... The three of them are laughing now.
answer: Skimmed milk...
